StarterSave FuelsUnit–V : Our Values
11
Let'sKnow Let'sKnowWe use different vehicles to travel from one place to another . Some of them 
run on fuels and some without fuel. Categorise the above means of transport under proper headings.
 Vehicles that run on fuels  Vehicles that run without fuels
 ___________________   ___________________
 ___________________   ___________________
 ___________________   ___________________
 ___________________   ___________________
What is Fuel?
Any material which is burn t to obtain ener gy is called fuel. The process by which 
this fuel is converted into ener gy is called combus tion. Modern- day vehicles use 
different types of fuels. Fuels can be divided into three groups–
 1.  Fossil fuels,              2. Renewable fuels,            3. Alterna tive fuels
Environmental Studies-5 80

Fossil Fuels
Fossil fuels are formed by the decomposition of dead plan ts and animal matter 
buried deep in the earth's crust. They take millions of years to form. Coal, 
petroleum and natural gas are naturally occurring fossil fuels. They are non-
renewable sour ces of ener gy.
Coal
Coal– Coal is a flammable black har d rock used as a solid fuel. It is a sedimen tary 
rock.
Forma tion of coal–  The dense forests in low lying wetland areas were buried under 
the soil due to natural factors. Mor e and more soil got deposit ed over them. Under 
high pressur e and high temper ature, they turned into coal gradually .
Uses of coal–  
!  It is used in rural areas for cooking and 
heating etc.
! It is used in power plan ts to gener ate 
electricity . 
! It is used in steam engines.
! It is used in various indus tries to gener ate 
power.
! Chemic als obtained from coal are used in the manuf acturing of dyes, pain ts 
etc. 
In India, the main coal reser ves are in Jharkhand ,West Beng al, Madh ya Pradesh, 
Andhr a Pradesh and Chha ttisgarh.
Petroleum
Petroleum– Petroleum is a thick black liquid fuel. It is also called black gold.
Forma tion of petroleum–  Petroleum is formed 
when dead sea animals and plan ts get buried 
under the seabed. Under high pressur e and 
temperature, they gradually turn into 
petroleum. 
Petroleum is a crude or unrefined oil. After 
refining in refineries different kinds of fuels 
such as petrol, diesel, kerosene etc. are 
produced.
Environmental Studies-581

Uses of various fuels / by products of petroleum– 
!  Petrol is used to run cars, two wheeler s etc. 
! Diesel is used to run heavy vehicles like buses ,truck s etc. It is also used to run 
gener ators.
! Jet fuel is used in aeroplanes.
! Bitumen ( coaltar) is used for construction of roads. 
! Paraffin w ax is used in c osme tics, polishes ,making c andles and in electric al 
insula tors.
! Grease and motor oil are used as lubric ants in vehicles and various machines.
Natural Gas
Natural gas– It is a gaseous fossil fuel. It is a clean and cheap fuel. 
Forma tion of natural gas- It is formed and obtained along with the petroleum in 
the oil wells. Gas wells are dug to obtain it.
Uses– 
! As LPG ( liquified petroleum gas), it is used as a domes tic and indus trial fuel.
!  As CNG( compr essed natural gas), it is used as fuel in vehicles because it 
causes less pollution. 
Renewable Fuel
Wood is a renewable fuel. When manag ed carefully, trees can be replan ted and 
grown to maturity to replace those that are cut down.
Alternative Fuels
! Fossil fuels take millions of years to form, so they cannot be replaced easily 
once their stock on earth finishes. Ther efore, it is better that we look for 
alterna tive fuels.
! Materials other than fossil fuels, that can be used as fuel are called alterna tive 
fuels.
! Following are some alterna tive sour ces of ener gy which are called renewable 
sour ces of ener gy. They are environmen t friendly i.e. they are non polluting 
fuels. In Greek, 'petr a' means ' rocks' and 'oleum ' means 'oil'. So, the word 'petr oleum ' 
means 'oil from rocks' .You  Know Must (Knowledge )
Environmental Studies-5 82

Key termsKey termsKey termsSolar ener gy– Ener gy from the sun is called solar ener gy. It is used for man y 
purposes–
  (i) It is converted into electric ener gy by solar panels.
 (ii) Solar cookers are used for cooking purposes.
Wind ener gy– Ener gy from moving wind is called wind ener gy. It is gener ated using 
windmills.
Hydro ener gy– Ener gy from moving water is called hydro ener gy. It is gener ated by 
hydel plan ts.
Conservation of Fossil Fuels
Coal and petroleum are precious natural resour ces. They are non renewable 
sour ces of ener gy. They take millions of years to form through a slow natural 
process. They will get exhaus ted if they are not used with due care. We mus t 
conser ve these fossil fuels by–
! Using alterna tive sour ces of ener gy such as solar ener gy, wind ener gy and 
water ener gy. 
!  Avoiding their wastage and using them efficien tly. 
! By using bicycles and cycle-rick shaws for going short distances.
! By car pooling or using public transport like buses and metro trains to reduce 
the number of vehicles on the road.
By conser ving fossil fuels we can sustain our fossil fuel reser ves for a long er time. It 
can also sa ve a lot of mone y for our g overnmen t, which c an then be used f or the 
developmen t of the country.
ŸRenewable  – That can be formed again and again.
ŸNon-r enewable – That cannot be formed again
ŸCrude   – That has not been purified.
Environmental Studies-583

ŸMos t of the vehicles need ener gy to move. This ener gy is supplied by fuel.
Ÿ Fossil fuels are essen tially the remains of plan ts and animals.
ŸAll fuels are expensiv e, so they mus t be used with due care.
Ÿ Natural gas is found along with petroleum.
I. Tick (3) the correct option  : (MC Qs) 
 (a) Any material that is burn t to obtain ener gy is called–
  coal oil fuel
 (b) Fossil fuels are essen tially the remains of –
  plan ts animals both 'a' and 'b'
 (c) This is not a fossil fuel–
  coal wood petroleum
 (d) An example of alterna te fuel is–
  solar ener gy diesel petrol
 (e) Fuel which causes less pollution is –
  diesel petrol CNG

StarterDignity of Labour12
Let'sKnow Let'sKnowWe all work. Without work, no one can lead a happ y life. Work provides us a 
health y life and mone y to live. W e cannot do all the w ork our selves. Ther e are 
man y people who help us lead a comfortable life. They provide us man y services 
which are essen tial for us. These people are called helper s. Imagine,. wha t 
would happen if the sweeper s do not come to sweep the roads in our colon y.Given belo w are the pictur es of some of our helper s without whom we 
cannot live a comfortable life. Recogniz e them and write the work they do.
Essential Services
The services needed everyday are called essen tial services. Let us read about some 
people who provide essen tial service.
! A washerman washes and irons our clothes.
! A milkman deliv ers milk at our houses.
! A cobbler mends our shoes.
! A plumber fixes our water pipes and leakages.
! A scrap dealer takes away the junk from our houses.
! A sweeper collects garbag e and sweeps the roads.
Environmental Studies-587Unit–V : Our Values

! A driver drives a bus or car and takes us to our destination.
! A security guar d keeps our neighbourhood safe.
! A mechanic repair s our cars, scooters, cycles etc.
All Jobs Are Dignified
A job is some work that we do specially to earn some mone y. Some jobs may 
requir e a person to apply his or her mind e.g. a teacher or a doct or etc. Some 
people's job is to perform some kind of physical labour e.g. a farmer , carpen ter or a 
mechanic etc.
We should respect all kinds of jobs and the people engaged in them. This is called 
dignity of labour .
Case Study
Sunanda is a garbag e collect or in a colon y. She wakes up at 
4:00 a.m. and comes to her duty at 6:00 a.m. She sweeps 
the roads and collects garbag e from the houses. She feels 
sad and humiliated when some children call her 
'Kachr awali'. She feels happ y when childr en addr ess her as 
'didi' or 'aun ty'. It brings a smile on her face and gives her 
the dignity she deser ves.
No W ork is Unclean
In earlier times, people who did menial w ork w ere consider ed un touchables and 
were depriv ed of basic social facilities. Their childr en were not permit ted to study 
with the childr en of upper castes. Even today, such prejudices are prevalen t in 
some regions.
On the other hand, the work of a sweeper in European countries gets as much 
respect as any other work. In fact, the studen ts there take up jobs like sweeping 
waitressing etc. to earn mone y and support themselv es while studying.
Mahatma Gandhi, the Father of Nation, respected 
dignity of labour . He did not feel shy to do any work. 
Man y a times he cleaned toilets as he wanted to chang e 
the attitude of people towards the so called 'dirty' work. 
He named untouchables as 'Harijans' which means 
'Childr en of God'.
Environmental Studies-5 88

Key termsKey termsKey termsBaba Saheb Bhimrao Ambedkar was one of the first 
'untouchables' to obtain a colleg e educ ation in India. He fough t 
for the rights of people like him and became famous across the 
world.
ŸHumilia ted  – Dishonour ed.
ŸDepriv ed of  – Not allow ed.
ŸPrejudices  – Unfair opinion about somebody or some thing.Dr. B. R. Ambedkar became the first Law and Justice Minister of 
Independ ent India.You  Know Must (Knowledge )
ŸDignity of labour means to respect all kinds of jobs and the people engaged in 
them.
Ÿ People who sweep the roads, clean the sewage, repair our shoes or fix the 
leaking pipes and taps are as import ant in our lives as the doct ors, engineer s 
or office workers.
Ÿ People engaged in different occupa tions should be addr essed respectfully .
I. Tick (3) the correct option  : (MC Qs) 
 (a) We should treat everyone with–
  anger respect carelessly
 (b) All people need to do some work to–
  stay health y earn a living both 'a' and 'b'TIME TO ANSWER
TO ANSWERTO ANSWER TIME

IV. Answer the following ques tions :

Let'sKnow Let'sKnow
India has a rich past and history. Several buildings and monumen ts were built 
by famous ruler s or people in the past  to show their power, prosperity and 
influence. These monumen ts are a part of our country's herit age.Starter
What is Heritage Building
A building which is consider ed by the governmen t to have historic, cultur al or 
architectur al value is called a herit age building. Forts, palaces, places of worship, 
tomb s etc. are some different types of herit age buildings.
A monumen t gives lot of informa tions to the historians e.g. the person who built it, 
materials used, the style of architectur e and the purpose of building it. Let us learn 
about some famous Indian monumen ts. ____________1 ____________2 ____________3Our Heritage Buildings13
See the pictur es given above. Name the monumen ts and the cities wher e they are 
located.Unit–V : Our Values
Some Monuments of Ancient India
Sanchi Stupa at Sanchi
Ashok a the Great is credited with having built about 84,000 stupas. The mos t 
Environmental Studies-5 92

famous one is situa ted at Sanchi. It's gate 
tells about the highes t aesthetic sense of the 
artis ts of those times.
The iron pillar at Mehr auli in New Delhi was 
built by early Gupta king, Chandr agup ta II in 
the ancien t times. It shows the developed 
state of metal casting in those Times. This 
metal pillar is smooth and unrus ted even 
after such a long time. 
Rock Cut T emples at Mahabalipuram
The Rock cut temples at Mahabalipur am 
were built by the great Pallava king, 
Narasimha varman. These temples are cut 
out of rocks with fine sculp tures on them.Iron Pillar at New Delhi
Brihadiswara T emple 
at Thanjavur
It was built by the Chola King , Rajar aja. It 
consis ts of 14 storeys and rises to a heigh t of 
190 feet. It contains very beautiful sculp tures 
and decorations.
Some Monuments of Medieval India
The R ed Fort
The Red fort ( Lal Qila) of Delhi is a master piece of architectur e. It was built by the 
Mughal emper or Shah Jahan in the 17th century. It is made of red sand stone. 
Inside the Red fort, we find a number of palaces wher e the emper or and the royal 
family lived. We also find the Diwan-i-Aam wher e the king could mee t the common 
Environmental Studies-593

The Red Fort's constru ction was complet ed over a span of 10 years, 
between 1638 and 1648. You  Know Must (Knowledge )people, and the Diwan-i-Khas wher e he could 
mee t his minis ters and advisor s. Some other 
chief sights within the fort are- Delhi Gate, 
Lahori Gate, Meena Bazaar, Justice Court, 
Moti Masjid, Zaffer Mahal etc.
Qutub Minar
This magnificen t structur e in the southern part 
of Delhi, is the talles t minar et in India ( 72 
metres high). The Muslim king Qutub-ud-din 
Aibak began it's construction in 1199 A.D. He 
built only one storey. His successor Iltutmish 
built more storeys. The first three storeys are 
made up of red sands tone and the fourth and 
fifth of marble and sands tone. It contains a lot 
of informa tion in the form of inscrip tions. 
The T aj Mahal
The Taj Mahal at Agra is the fines t piece of 
architectur e in India and is included among the 
Seven W onder s of the W orld. It w as built with 
whit e marble by Mughal emper or Shah Jahan 
in the memor y of his wife, Mum taz Mahal. 
About 20,000 artisans and crafts people 
worked for nearly 20 years to build this 
monumen t.
Jantar Mantar
Raja Jai Singh of Amber( now Jaipur) promot ed scien tific learning. He built five 
observatories during his rule in the 18th century. These observatories are called 
Environmental Studies-5 94

Some Monuments of Modern India
Gateway of India at Mumbai
This monumen t was built during the British 
rule in India. It served as a ceremonial 
entrance to welcome king Geor ge V on his 
visit to India in 1911. That was the first visit 
of any British monarch to India. It 
symbolises the grandeur of British empir e 
and also witnesses the departur e of the last 
British troops from India. 
Rashtrapati Bhawan at New Delhi
It is the grand residence of the presiden t of 
India. It was built during the British rule and 
took 17 years for its comple tion(1912-1929). 
Originally built as a residence for the Vicer oy 
of India, it was then called Vicer oy's House but 
today it is emblema tic of Indian democr acy.
Golden T emple at Amritsar
This Holy pilgrimag e of Sikhs was built by 
Guru Ramdas, the fourth Guru of the Sikhs. 
The main enclosur e is embossed with gold, 
hence, it is called the Golden Temple. 
Jantar Man tar. Among these five, the one in 
Delhi w as the fir st to be built. The other f our 
are at Mathur a, Ujjain, Jaipur and Banar as. 
Jantar Man tar is not only a time keeper of 
celes tial bodies, it also tells us a lot about the 
technologic al achie vemen ts under the Rajput 
kings and their attempts to solve the 
mysteries regarding astronom y.
Environmental Studies-595

Akshardham T emple at New Delhi
Situa ted in the heart of India, New Delhi, this 
monument encapsulates 10,000 years of 
Indian history in all of its awe-inspiring 
grandeur and beauty . It look s fabulous with its 
sculp tures, carvings and lush green gardens. It 
is one of the mos t intricate religious places of 
worship ever construct ed and truly a modern 
day wonder of the world.
Conserving the Heritage
It is the responsibility of all the citizens to protect herit age as they are our pride and  
a windo w to look into the past. We mus t follow the following ways to protect 
them–
! We mus t not write anything on the walls of monumen ts.
! We should not throw waste in or around these places.
! We mus t purchase a ticket for the entry as this mone y is used for the 
main tenance of the monumen ts.
! We should not try to damag e the monumen t.
Key termsKey termsKey terms
Environmental Studies-5 96ŸHerit age   – Some thing that is handed down from the past and 
has great import ance.
ŸInscrip tions  – Words that are written or cut on something; 
(Engr avings)
ŸSculp ture   – The three dimensional represen tation of some thing 
by carving stone or wood or by casting metal or 
plaster.
ŸAesthetic   – Concerned with beauty or art.
Ÿ Grandeur   – Splendor / quality of being grand impr essiv e.
Ÿ Emblema tic  — Symbolic.
Ÿ Encapsulates  – Encloses.

TIME TO ANSWER

 (b) Gateway of India is in Delhi.
 (c) The Taj Mahal is one of the Seven Wonder s of the world.ŸIndia is rich in cultur e, tradition, herit age buildings and monumen ts.

IV. Answer the following ques tions :

StarterEvery Drop is PreciousUnit–VI : Environment
14
Let'sKnow Let'sKnowRivers, lakes, ponds, oceans and seas are the various water bodies. Rain is the 
major sour ce of water on the earth. Water covers more than two-thir d of 
earth's surface. But the amoun t of fresh drinking water is less than 1%. The 
rest is either salty water or is presen t in the form of ice-c aps.
Water in its pure form has no smell, colour and taste. It appear s to be an 
ordinar y substance but its import ance in our lives is extraordinar y. It supports 
life in various ways. It is used for drinking , cooking , washing and cleaning , for 
growing crops, for transport ation, for producing electricity and man y more 
things. Water is the life-blood of the indus tries. Indus tries use more than half 
of the water available for human use.
Groundw ater is the major sour ce of w ater in man y parts of the w orld. But it 
has been continuously deple ting due to overexploit ation by rising human 
popula tion and the rapid rise in indus trializ ation and urbaniz ation. So, we 
should use water judiciously .In your pr evious classes, y ou ha ve studied about v arious sour ces of w ater. See 
the pictur es given belo w and name the sour ces of water.
____________ ____________ ____________ ____________
Environmental Studies-5 100

22 M arch is c elebr ated every year as the W orld W ater Da y.You  Know Must (Knowledge )
Ancient Sources of W ater
In ancien t times, mos t of the sour ces of water were located away from homes and 
belong ed to the entire community . People had to cover long distances to mee t 
their water needs. One of them was the baoli (step-w ell).
Baolis or Step-w ells– In ancien t times in North India, 
baolis were built to ensur e that a city would have 
constant water supply . They are still in use in man y 
parts of Rajas than and other places.
A baoli has two parts– a vertic al shaft from which 
water is drawn and the surrounding steps that 
provide access to the well. These steps were used by 
local people as a cool resting place during hot 
summer s. Baolis were so effectiv e in providing clean drinking water to the people 
that efforts are on to revive even those old baolis that are lying unused for a long 
period of time.
In India, ther e are man y famous baolis lik e Rajon ki Baoli (Delhi), Agr asen ki Baoli 
(Delhi) and Chand Baoli (Rajas than) The Chand Baoli in Rajas than is the largest 
baoli in the world.
The Bundi district in Rajasthan has around 301 baolis. It is also known 
as the 'City of stepwells' .You  Know Must (Knowledge )
Water in Our Home
We cannot drink water available in water bodies directly . Before sending it to our 
houses, the Water Works Departmen t 
treats and cleans it to mak e it fit for 
drinking and other purposes. 
Sometimes, this water may still 
contain man y impurities. So, it is better 
to filter tap water before drinking.
Environmental Studies-5101

Pollution of W ater
In nature or due to human activities, man y harm ful substances get mixed in water 
sour ces and mak e water unfit for use. This is called water pollution. Some of the 
reasons of water pollution are–
! Dust particles and harm ful gases presen t in the air.
! Dung of animals.
! Rubbish and garbag e thrown in water.
! Indus trial waste which flows into water.
! Water from sewage and drains flowing into water bodies.
! Washing clothes and bathing animals near water sour ces.
Ways to Control W ater P ollution 
! Dirty water should not be allowed to collect near the sour ces of water.
! Harm ful w aste from f actories, indus tries e tc. should not be dumped in to or 
near the sour ces of water.
! Avoid throwing wastes into the water sour ces.
! Avoid washing clothes and bathing animals near water sour ces.
Diseases Spread From Stagnant W ater
The water left standing anywher e for long periods of time, is called stagnan t water. 
Stagnan t water becomes a prime breeding place for mosquit oes, bact eria, fungi 
and other micr obes.
A mosquit o is an insect that breeds in stagnan t  water and spreads some of the 
worst diseases like malaria, dengue, filariasis and yellow fever etc.
Malaria– Malaria is a life threatening disease. It is spread through the bites of 
infected female Anopheles mosquit oes. People suffering from malaria  usually feel 
very sick with a high fever and shaking chills. In severe cases it can cause seizures, 
coma or death. Blood tests can help diagnose malaria by detecting the presence of 
malaria parasite in the blood.
Prevention of Malaria and Dengue
Preventing diseases like malaria and dengue is not the responsibility of 
governmen t alone. It is the duty of the individuals and the community to follow the 
instructions issued by the governmen t during the outbr eak of such a disease. 
Some of the tips to prevent such diseases are– 
Environmental Studies-5 102

Key termsKey termsKey terms! As far as possible, avoid travelling in areas wher e these diseases are already 
spreading.
! Wear long sleeved clothes to protect yourself from mosquit o bites.
! Do not allow water to stagna te in your surroundings.
! If there is any stagnan t water, spray kerosene oil over the water to prevent 
breeding of mosquit oes.
! Use a mosquit o net or mosquit o repellen ts while sleeping.
! Fix wire screens to the windows and have netted doors to prevent 
mosquit oes from flying into the house.
These diseases can be controlled if we are cautious and keep our surroundings 
clean. Quinine, a medicine made from the cinchona plan t, help s in treating 
Properties of W ater
Water is the univ ersal solvent– A solvent is a liquid that can dissolv e another 
substance in it. Water is called the univ ersal solvent because it can dissolv e mos t of 
the substances in it. The substance that dissolv es in a liquid is called a solut e.
For example– In a sugar solution, sugar is the solut e and water is the solvent. 
Floa ting and Sinking–  Do you know why certain things float in water, while some 
other s sink?
This is because different objects have different densities. Density is the heaviness 
or ligh tness of an object . Objects tha t are ligh t and ha ve less density than w ater, 
such as a feather or a leaf, will always float on the surface of water. On the other 
hand, if the density of the object is more than that of water, such as a piece of iron 
or a stone, the object will sink.
Soluble and Insoluble substances– Some substances like salt and sugar dissolv e in 
water readily . They are called soluble substances. Substance like sand and wood do 
not dissolv e in water at all. They are called insoluble substances.
ŸIndus trializ ation – Rapid increase in indus tries.
ŸUrbaniz ation  – Increase in people shifting from villag es to cities and 
towns.
ŸJudiciously  – Wisely .
Ÿ Density   – Heaviness or lightness of an object.
